  • Ryan Wesslen

Large Language Models are Clinical Reasoners: Reasoning-Aware Diagnosis Framework with Prompt-Generated Rationales

New framework uses prompt-based learning for efficient clinical reasoning in disease diagnosis, demonstrating potential for real-world clinical settings.

prompt engineering
Author

gpt-3.5-turbo-1106

Published

December 12, 2023

Large Language Models are Clinical Reasoners: Reasoning-Aware Diagnosis Framework with Prompt-Generated Rationales

Introduction

  • LLMs demonstrated capacity for reasoning.
  • Most NLP-driven clinical projects lack clinical reasoning for disease diagnosis.
  • Proposed framework rationalizes diagnostic process and clinical CoT reasoning.

Problem Formulation

  • Clinical reasoning connects patient description and diagnosis.
  • Absence of effective clinical reasoning leads to diagnostic errors.

Testbed: Alzheimer’s Disease Diagnosis

  • AD diagnosis chosen due to the disease’s complexity.
  • Patient description includes MRI scan, demographic info, educational level, MMSE results, and APOE4 allele presence.

Reasoning-Aware Diagnosis Framework

  • Framework involves clinical rationalization, few-shot reasoning, and knowledge distillation.
  • Empirical evidence shows better performance in disease diagnosis and human-like reasoning.

Experiments

  • Used ADNI and AIBL datasets.
  • Implemented LLMs, unimodal-student models, and multimodal-student models.
  • Results indicate improved diagnostic performance and data efficiency.

Results and Discussion

  • Clinically meaningful rationales improve AD diagnosis.
  • Knowledge distillation benefits small models.
  • Framework is helpful in data-scarce scenarios.
  • Ineffective rationales not the cause of misdiagnoses.

Clinician Study: Quality of Rationales

  • Proposed criteria to evaluate machine-generated rationales for clinical diagnosis.
  • Human evaluation indicates effective replication of clinician reasoning.

Case Study of Machine-generated Rationales

  • Contextual interpretation of clinical evidence and selective summarization observed.

Related Work

  • Previous methods focus on classification or reading comprehension without addressing clinical reasoning.

Conclusion

  • Proposed framework facilitates clinical reasoning for disease diagnosis.
  • Limitations include prompt length and need for real-world implementation.

Ethical Consideration and Societal Impacts

  • Patient data is de-identified for privacy.
  • Ongoing assessment for societal impacts needed.

Acknowledgements

  • Supported by various institutions.

References

  • Detailed in-text references included in the summarized content.
